Example

This example will help you to see how continuous random variables arise and will help you to distinguish between continuous and discrete random variables.

Consider a de-magnetised compass needle mounted at its centre so that it can spin freely. Its initial position is shown in Figure 1(a). It is spun clockwise and when it comes to rest the angle \(θ\), from the vertical, is measured. See Figure 1(b).


"angle \(θ\) measured after each spin".

Firstly, note that \(X\) is a random variable since it can take any value in the interval \(0\) to \(2\pi\) and we cannot be sure in advance which value it will take. However, after each spin and thinking in probability terms, there are certainly two distinct questions we can ask.

  • What is the probability that \(X\) lies between two values \(a, b\), i.e. what is \(\text{P}(a < X < b)\)?
  • What is the probability that \(X\) assumes a particular value, say \(c\). We are really asking what is the value of \(\text{P}(X = c)\)?

The first question is easy to answer provided we assume that the probability of the needle coming to rest in a given interval is given by the formula:

\(\text{Probability} = \dfrac{\text{Given interval in radians}}{\text{Total interval in radians}}=\dfrac{\text{Given interval in radians}}{2\pi}.\)

The following results are easily obtained and they clearly coincide with what we intuitively feel is correct:

(a) \(\text{P} (0 < X < \dfrac{\pi}{2}) = \dfrac{1}{4}\) since the interval \(\left(0, \dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)\) covers one quarter of a full circle.
(b) \(\text{P} (\dfrac{\pi}{2} < X < 2\pi) = \dfrac{3}{4}\); since the interval \(\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}, 2\pi\right)\) covers three quarters of a full circle.

It is easy to see the generalization of this result for the interval \((a, b)\), in which both \(a, b\) lie in the interval \(\left(0, 2\pi\right)\) :

\(\text{P}(a < X< b)=\dfrac{b-a}{2\pi}.\)

The second question immediately presents problems! In order to answer a question of this kind would require a measuring device (e.g. a protractor) with infinite precision: no such device exists nor could one ever be constructed. Hence it can never be verified that the needle, after spinning, takes any particular value; all we can be reasonably sure of is that the needle lies between two particular values.

We conclude that in experiments of this kind we never determine the probability that the random variable assume a particular value but only calculate the probability that it lies within a given range of values. This kind of random variable is called a continuous random variable and it is characterised, not by probabilities of the type \(\text{P}(X = c)\) (as was the case with a discrete random variable), but by a function \(f(x)\) called the probability density function (pdf for short). In the case of the rotating needle this function takes the simple form given with corresponding plot:

Figure: Plot of the pdf

where definition of the pdf is given by \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{1}{2\pi} & \text{for all $ 0\leq x < 2\pi$} \\ 0 & \text{elsewhere} \end{cases}. \]     

The probability \(\text{P}(a < X < b)\) is the area under the function curve \(f(x)\) and so is given by the integral \[\displaystyle{\int_a^b f(x) \; dx}.\]

Suppose we wanted to find \(\text{P}(\dfrac{\pi}{6} < X < \dfrac{\pi}{4}).\) Then using the definition of the pdf for this case:

\(\text{P}(\dfrac{\pi}{6} < X < \dfrac{\pi}{4})= \displaystyle{\int_{\tiny{\dfrac{\pi}{6}}}^{\tiny{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}} \dfrac{1}{2\pi} \; dx} = \left. \dfrac{x}{2\pi} \right \vert_{\tiny{\dfrac{\pi}{6}}}^{ \tiny{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}} = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}-\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)=\dfrac{1}{2\pi} \cdot \dfrac{\pi}{12}=\dfrac{1}{24}.\)

This is reasonable since the interval \(( \dfrac{\pi}{6}, \dfrac{\pi}{4})\) is one twenty-fourth of the interval \(0\) to \(2\pi\).

In general terms we have

\(\text{P}(a<X<b)= \displaystyle{\int_a^b f(t) \; dt} = F(b)-F(a) = \dfrac{b-a}{2\pi}\)

for the pdf under consideration here. Note also that

(a) \(f(x) \geq 0,\) for all real \(x\)

(b) \(\displaystyle{\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}} f(x) \; dx = \int_0^{2\pi} \dfrac{1}{2\pi} \; dx = 1,\) i.e. total probability is \(1\).

We are now in a position to give a formal definition of a continuous random variable in the following Key Point.

Key Point

\(X\) is said to be a continuous random variable if there exists a function \(f(x)\) associated with \(X\) called the probability density function with the properties

  • \(f(x) \geq 0\) for all \(x\);
  • \(\displaystyle{\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}} f(x) \; dx = 1 \);
  • \(\text{P}(a < X < b) = \displaystyle{\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) \; dx = F(b) -F(a) \).

The first two bullet points in the above Key Point are the analogues of the results \(\text{P}(X = x_i) ≥ 0\) and \(\displaystyle{\sum_i P(X = x_i) =1 }\) for discrete random variables.
